Tadpoles attach to e. substrate within an hour or two after hatch.i.nge The mete-
morphoeis is extremely rapid (Grave "35, Grave and Iiichol, They often netamor->>

bo  -old form atrial buddy., Allow tadpolee to attach to wa;/ch glasses and
grow for ltwo days. They are now larger and clearer, and usually so oriented that the
observer looks directly down into the atrial and oral sipnons., The large pharynx is in
the shape of a truncated cone and bears the three rows of stigmata which let eater pass
out into the atrial cavities of the two sides., The endoetyle lies on the underside of
the pharynx and thus appears as a rod under the mouth.,
The stomach ordinarily appears as a yellow body under the atrial opening., The
intestine after turning to one side from the stomach, returns to empty near the atriume
The pulsating heart and its vessels are of particular interest, especially the flow of
blood around the mouth and pharynx., 
renew bud (first biaewzcoia) appears from the sexually developed animal (uw oozcid)
as an evagination of the atrium at one side. It is furnished with a blood supply, and
presently the differentiating parts can be distinguished., Coming from the atrium, the
whole bud, and all parts of the new individual, are derived from ectoderm. This is the
atrial type of budding (lerrill, 
c. Week-old forms Will be providede In these animals, general struc%e already
studied may be easily seen under low power. The pharynx of the oozooid developed
4 mira of stigmata, and the first blastozooid may also have three or four rows., Blasto-
sooid buds of the second and third order may be presents
The first blastozooid bud in is single, all the later ones are in symmet-
rical pairs. The same organ structures may be seen in all the individuals, not with-
etauding their diverse enbryology, with the minor exception that the oozooid does not
develop gonads. Through rearrangement of the individuals, the completed colony shows a.
cormnon atrial pit in the center, with separate pharyngeal openings at the periphery
(see wall chart). 
Each bud consists at first of a disc, then a sphere., The sphere extrudes sex cells
at one or both sides and becomes partitioned into three vesiclese the ,lateral ones
forming an-iai chambers, me middle one the pharymce (Later stages show differentiation
of the rest oi' the organs from the Berrill, 
3. geropgrae Perophora is a little green-colored ascidian, which by means of
stolons foms loose colonies on wharf pilings, etc. Pieces of the colony may be gently
stuck to watch glasses withpvaseline, and stored in running sea waters After a day or
so,sto1ons will be sent 'out over the surface of the glass and new blastozocids will be
formed' at intervals. Examine the watch glass culture of -Perophora which has been grow->>
ing for two weaker 
Notice the branching pattern of the stolonss The tips show exploratory tendencies 
like small pseudopodia. The outgo;Ln.g; and incoming blood streams in the stolons are 
separated by a septume .A11 the stages in the formation of new individuals 
will be found, arranged like pumpkins on a vine, with the youngest nearest the tipse
